title: Innoquest - Hack with Copilot
description: At Innoquest, we challenge participants to immerse themselves in understanding disability and innovating technologies to enhance accessibility. In this hackathon, your team will have 30 hours to conceptualize a new assistive technology or a solution that addresses an accessibility barrier faced by people with disabilities. You can focus on any single disability or multiple disabilities. Your prototype can range from sketches and paper prototypes to digital mock-ups‚Äîuse your strengths to demonstrate your commitment to accessibility. When planning your project, we strongly encourage you to connect with people with disabilities to learn firsthand about what would make the world more accessible to them. If you or someone on your team is disabled, consider projects that will address your own accessibility barriers. By engaging in conversations with disabled individuals and learning about their experiences, you will gain valuable insights that will inform the development of meaningful and impactful prototypes. Remember, the ultimate goal of Innoquest is to empower disabled individuals and promote inclusivity through innovative solutions. Best of luck on your journey of discovery and innovation!

title: HackMaze
description:
IoSC EDC invites you to embark on a thrilling and transformative journey - HackMaze**.** This innovative project-based legion is designed to empower contestants like you with the incredible capabilities of oneAPI toolkits. Get ready to explore, learn, and create like never before!

The Hackathon is structured in two stages: An Online Preliminary Round and an Offline Final round. In the online preliminary round, participants are required to create a presentation that explains the architecture of their projects. This presentation should include elements including, but not limited to, flowcharts and high-level system diagrams, details about the tech-stack used, and a peek into how Intel Developer Cloud is supposed to be integrated into the project's framework.

Round 1: Online Submission Round

In this online qualifying round, participants must submit a comprehensive presentation to showcase their project effectively.

Maintain professionalism, adhere to guidelines.

Note: Participants are required to use Intel Developer Cloud, irrespective of the chosen track. Projects incorporating the Intel oneAPI Developer toolkit will receive preference in the final evaluation, further highlighting the significance of Intel's technologies in this competition.

The Presentation must follow the guidelines mentioned below:

1. Title and Team Introduction:

‚óè A compelling title that encapsulates the essence of your project.

‚óè Mention LinkedIn and GitHub IDs of your team members.

2. Project Overview:

‚óè Present a concise and precise overview of your project's objectives and goals.

‚óè Spotlight the salient features and functionalities that your project delivers.

3. Architectural Insight:

‚óè Comprehensive flowcharts or system diagrams illustrating the key components and their interactions.

‚óè A clear depiction of the data flow within the system.

4. Interface(overview):

‚óè Display the user interface design, including screenshots or mock-ups of key screens.

‚óè Explain how the design choices align with the project's goals and objectives.

5. Intel Developer Cloud Integration(Mandatory):

‚óè Explain your utilisation of the Intel Developer Cloud and oneAPI toolkits(use of toolkits is optional).

6. Application:

‚óè Future scope and elaborate the application of your project in real-world and financial potential.

It is imperative that your presentation remains polished, coherent, and visually engaging. Utilize visual aids such as diagrams, charts, and relevant screenshots to enhance comprehension.

Round 2: Offline Project Showcase Round

The Top 25 teams from the first round will be shortlisted and invited to bring their submitted ideas to life by creating projects, and it's mandatory that they utilize the Intel Developer Cloud, as specified in the previous round. The teams will showcase their projects offline in front of our esteemed panel of judges at GGSIPU EDC. Further details will be communicated to the qualifying teams. Good luck with your projects!

Above all, ensure that your presentation effectively conveys the inventive and impactful nature of your project, all within the framework and guidelines set forth for the hackathon

Creating an effective and engaging presentation requires a clear and concise problem statement, a detailed technical stack, standing out from others, innovation beyond the problem statement and a highlighted team. Also make sure that the design elements are in sync between the slide deck and the prototype. Keep in mind that the design choices can make or break the presentation, so it's essential to put thought and effort into the aesthetic of your presentation.

Submission Format-

2. Presentation with the following mandatory slides (adding anything else is optional)¬†¬†Maximum Slides (8 Slides)

  • Problem Statement
  • Architecture
  • How your idea is outstand from others
  • Challenges faced
  • Future Scope

title: Interestship 5.0
description:
Clique Community in collaboration with SheBuildsOnAzure, Azure Developer Community & IEEE Gujrat Section is proud to announce the upcoming launch of Interestship 5.0 following the successful completion of four previous Interestships. Participants from various universities across India, who possessed impressive skills and a good CGPA, took part in the event. Our previous program participants have proven themselves to be true visionaries, showcasing their talent and completing captivating projects with the help of mentors.

These projects ranged from building an Android Application for a restaurant menu card,designing a fully functional farmer-friendly web app for bio-waste trading, creating a stunning UI for an e-commerce website, developing a Sports Event Management System using Spring Boot and Java Development , participated in Technical Content Writing , predicting future sales and mastering time series analysis using Data Science , working on OCR for credit cards using cutting-edge Computer Vision techniques, and building a React Authentication App using OKTA within a span of 4 weeks.

title: Moreficent App-A-Thon
description:
Moreficent can help improve the learning outcomes of¬†students by providing a professional-grade programming environment running on good hardware.

We run standard desktop applications, like Android Studio, in the cloud and stream the user interface to the browser. Through a combination of advances in algorithms and the adoption of cutting-edge standards, we are able to make the remote application feel as responsive as the one running locally.

With our approach, there is no loss of productivity, either because of laggy user interfaces (as with other remote desktop solutions) or needing to adjust workflows or course materials (as with other remote programming setups). At the same time, you get to take advantage of the limitless resources of the cloud for faster builds, modern streaming technology for better collaboration between students and doubt resolution between students and teachers, and replicating a standard programming setup across all students, so that they don‚Äôt need to spend time dealing with boilerplate.

As we grow the platform, we want to collaborate with student and professional clubs as technology partners for their events. The benefits we offer are better hardware for running Android Studio, better collaboration and reduced setup times

Hackathons are to be around mobile development and all projects should be built using Moreficent.

title: Green Charcoal Hackathon
description:
Power plants are the biggest consumers of coal. Typically a 1000 MW plant consumes about 5 million tonnes of coal annually. India's total coal-based power generation capacity is about 2 lakh MW, which theoretically can consume approximately 1000 million tonnes of coal annually.

Even 10% of that, if replaced with torrefied charcoal will amount to 100 million tonnes of this fuel which will require approximately 165 MTPA of agro residue (considering 60% yield), sufficient to wipe out the entire unused agro residue in the country and thus eliminating the farm fires and produce approx. 20,000 MW of renewable power. The idea has vast potential to increase rural income, provide local employment, cleaning the air by eliminating farm fires and also to generate enormous renewable energy with existing coal power infrastructure.

The technology to produce torrefied fuel using agro residue biomass is not easily accessible to small entrepreneurs due to the higher cost of imported machines, lack of sufficient manufacturers, and non-availability of the torrefaction plants having smaller capacity suitable for cottage industry entrepreneurs. To fast-track the development the technology for converting agro residue to charcoals, NVVN, a wholly owned subsidiary of NTPC limited, in partnership with EESL plans to organise a technology challenge Green Charcoal Hackathon. It will leverage the innovative Indian mind to bridge the technology gap, with the prime objective to clean the air by eliminating farm fire, producing renewable energy out of the agro residue, to promote local entrepreneurship, and to increase the income of the farmers.

title: Smart Mobility Hackathon
description:
Nearly half a million road accidents happen every year in India and over hundred and fifty thousand people die every year. Those numbers are comparable to some of the most major natural disasters or even epidemics. Yet road safety elicits less attention that it should. The brightest minds of our generation are making mobility awesome by working on electric vehicles but the other part of making mobility awesome is to end the needless physical harm on our roads.

How can we make our roads safer ?¬†

There are many ways of making our roads safer: prevention and mitigations. Prevention is where we prevent an accident, mitigation is where we do better handling of accidents. Both can make a difference to overall lives lost on roads. Within prevention :

We can make roads safer by making safer infrastructure (better light conditions, signage, roads etc.). Let‚Äôs call them ‚ÄòWhere we drive‚Äô factors.¬†¬†

At another level we can make roads safer by making our vehicles safer - we could call them ‚ÄòWhat we drive‚Äô factors

And lastly we could just drive well - the ‚Äòhow we drive‚Äô factors.

Goes without saying that if we could improve the ‚Äòhow we drive‚Äô - we can achieve safety at the least cost and at an individual level. ‚ÄòWhere we drive‚Äô & ‚ÄòWhat we drive‚Äô is a much larger canvas of problem solving and needs many stakeholders to make a dent in the problem but ‚ÄòHow we drive‚Äô interventions can be driven faster. So we want to focus on them for this hackathon.

So how do we solve the problem of making our driving safer - how do we help people drive safer through awareness, through incentives, through gamification, how do we make sure that people are driving safely to start with. That would mean that they are driving within speed limits, not overtaking unnecessarily, braking slowly - so others can adjust, accelerate gently so others can figure out, keeping enough distance between their vehicles and so on.

For example: experts say that nearly a quarter of accidents happen because of distracted driving - with mobile usage a major part of the problem. So how do we stop people from using their mobile phones while driving ?
